data.title: Saturday's Children (1940)
data.meta_description: An inventor and his bride get testy in the city as they try to make ends meet.
data.text:
"Marriage is no love affair my dear."

On her first day at work Bobby (Anne Shirley) meets Rims (John Garfield) and the two fall for one another. But Rims has dreams of moving to the Philippines to work on an invention and the two will have to figure out what is more important, their relationship or his previous plans.

There's nothing boundary pushing or challenging about Saturday's Children. And there doesn't have to be. It's a quaint, pleasant romance where the darkest challenge that faces Bobby and Rims' marriage is the stress that comes from a lack of money and the strain it can put on a relationship. Even when the two are most at odds with each other their…

No one gets any respite in this lacklustre family drama centring money and marriage ensnared by the impossible demands of work, and the misfortunes of a labour market skewed by the anxieties of an approaching war. It is compelling for its depiction of the daily grind, with the constant struggle to keep one's head above financial waters, and this generational mindless acceptance of a soulless profession for the sake of a barely liveable salary. Both are entrenched in a merciless work culture that boasts of such normalcy. 'Every day is Monday' is an echoing sentiment throughout. Passion and paycheque are immiscible substances of an existence often hanging by the thread of survival. The romantic aspect of the film, developing from an…

Soooo wait.... WHY couldn't she just go to the Philippines with him?

And her reaction to her own dad trying to KILL HIMSELF, as a quick fix to their problems, was wildly inappropriate - "Oh, Dad! You big sil, you didn't have to go and do a thing like that! I love ya, you crazy lug, you!" ....ok, so those might not have been her exact words, but I'm not too far off.

She certainly wasn't shaken up about her father narrowly escaping the clutches of death, that's for sure.
